content:
Let’s take an History lesson and become familiar with the fantastic UNIX universe. Today I would like to talk about BSD and its status in 2019.
The most common BSD distros to date are: FreeBSD - Open BSD - NetBSD
Another interesting project based on FreeBSD is TrueOS.
The main differences between FreeBSD and OpenBSD are notable. The first one tries to develop a complete modern desktop system, facing some common problems that derive from it, the second one is completely focused on security and transparency, as well as being free from non-Open content, which in fact makes it one of the most secure by default distributions in the Open Source panorama.
I personally used FreeBSD and would like to focus on it. Recently, after a very long time and with great surprise, I found a complete Distro that is well suited to any use, so I kept a Server VM that I use to host some of my Services. In the future (on some spare time) I intend to publish benchmarks made using the Phoronix suite.
Unlike Linux which uses the ZoL porting of ZFS (not yet perfect), FreeBSD makes use of a native implementation of the ZFS Filesystem - it’s a win-win when it comes to storage management. The advantages in it using a filesystem such as ZFS are many and to be taken into consideration for mission-critical systems, resulting in a fairly simple and well documented configuration.
I was really surprised when I discovered that Netflix used FreeBSD on its proprietary Open Connect platforms to implement its CDN and managing to guarantee an impressive performance (up to 90 Gb / s) on TLS encrypted connections, keeping the CPU at 55% (16 cores at 2.6 Ghz). Source Netflix FOSDem 2019
An Open Connect appliance.
